title: Utilizing Assistive Technology to Reduce Caregiver Burden and Enhance Quality of Life in Individuals Living With Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias
description_brief: The study investigated a six-week randomized controlled trial study in a small cohort of 16 family caregivers of individuals living with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. Family caregivers used assistive technology in the form of visual mapping software on smart devices in the experimental condition to support their care recipients in carrying out activities of daily living. Family caregivers in the control condition viewed educational videos about dementia care on their devices in supporting their individuals. The intervention was implemented for a total of 6 weeks. The investigators hypothesized that compared to the caregivers using educational videos, the caregivers using assistive technology will report improved quality of life and completion of activities of daily living for their care recipients, all the while reducing caregiver's burden and stress.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is a non‑pharmacologic assistive technology (visual mapping software / MapHabit) delivered via smart devices to support activities of daily living and reduce caregiver burden — it is not a biologic or small molecule, nor a drug-based cognitive enhancer or a neuropsychiatric symptom medication. citeturn0search3turn0search1

Act: Key trial details extracted from the published report — a six‑week randomized controlled feasibility study of 16 family caregivers (experimental n=7, control n=9) comparing visual mapping assistive technology (step‑by‑step pictures/audio/video to guide ADLs) versus educational videos; outcomes were improved quality of life and ADL completion for care recipients and reduced caregiver burden in the assistive‑technology group. This identifies the study as a behavioral/technology intervention rather than any drug or biologic. citeturn0search3turn0search0

Reflect: Classification check — by definitions: (1) Disease‑targeted biologic = monoclonal antibodies/vaccines targeting pathology — not present; (2) Disease‑targeted small molecule = pharmacologic agents targeting pathology — not present; (3) Cognitive enhancer = drug intended to improve cognition pharmacologically — not present; (4) Neuropsychiatric symptom improvement = pharmacologic or behavioral treatments aimed at BPSD — while this trial aims to improve ADLs/QOL and reduce caregiver burden (behavioral outcomes), it is an assistive‑technology behavioral intervention. Therefore the correct category is 'N/A' (does not fit the four therapeutic drug/biologic categories). citeturn0search3
